content.raw: I'll make a prerelease of this so we can test the ign-physics plugin with CI
content.html: I'll make a prerelease of this so we can test the ign-physics plugin with CI

content.raw: Ah, sorry, I forgot that the vanilla `Plugin` class isn’t a template.
content.html: Ah, sorry, I forgot that the vanilla Plugin class isn’t a template.

content.raw:
Here's the diff between the `ign-plugin1` and this branch of the symbols in `ignition-plugin1.lib` 

```diff
19c19
<                   ??0Plugin@plugin@ignition@@AEAA@XZ (private: __cdecl ignition::plugin::Plugin::Plugin(void))
---
>                   ??0Plugin@plugin@ignition@@IEAA@XZ (protected: __cdecl ignition::plugin::Plugin::Plugin(void))
```
content.html:
Here's the diff between the ign-plugin1 and this branch of the symbols in ignition-plugin1.lib 

19c19
<                   ??0Plugin@plugin@ignition@@AEAA@XZ (private: __cdecl ignition::plugin::Plugin::Plugin(void))
---
>                   ??0Plugin@plugin@ignition@@IEAA@XZ (protected: __cdecl ignition::plugin::Plugin::Plugin(void))

content.raw: I don't believe we have yet created any binary artifacts on windows that use ign-plugin. So for now I think we could ignore ABI problems that only affect Windows
content.html: I don't believe we have yet created any binary artifacts on windows that use ign-plugin. So for now I think we could ignore ABI problems that only affect Windows

content.raw:
> These are all templates anyway, so the definitions of the symbols will exist in each compilation unit that ever used them.

Right, but `ignition::plugin::Plugin` is not a template and it's constructor has changed from private to protected.
content.html:
These are all templates anyway, so the definitions of the symbols will exist in each compilation unit that ever used them.

Right, but ignition::plugin::Plugin is not a template and it's constructor has changed from private to protected.

content.raw:
These are all templates anyway, so the definitions of the symbols will exist in each compilation unit that ever used them.

The difference in the symbol name would only matter if one library tried to use a version of the symbol as it was compiled by another library, which would require someone somewhere to have done an `extern template` declaration, which we’ve never done
content.html:
These are all templates anyway, so the definitions of the symbols will exist in each compilation unit that ever used them.

The difference in the symbol name would only matter if one library tried to use a version of the symbol as it was compiled by another library, which would require someone somewhere to have done an extern template declaration, which we’ve never done

content.raw: I read at http://madebyevan.com/obscure-cpp-features/ that MSVC includes access modifiers in its name mangling. https://community.kde.org/Policies/Binary_Compatibility_Issues_With_C%2B%2B also says "changing the access rights to some functions or data members, for example from private to public" is not ABI compatible.
content.html: I read at http://madebyevan.com/obscure-cpp-features/ that MSVC includes access modifiers in its name mangling. https://community.kde.org/Policies/Binary_Compatibility_Issues_With_C%2B%2B also says "changing the access rights to some functions or data members, for example from private to public" is not ABI compatible.

content.raw:
how do you feel about moving the `ComposePlugin` class back up here above the `SelectSpecializers` class (c6d9dd9)? I think it will make the diff a bit smaller

* #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/branch/improve_compile_times_scpeters?dest=ign-plugin1#diff
content.html:
how do you feel about moving the ComposePlugin class back up here above the SelectSpecializers class (c6d9dd9)? I think it will make the diff a bit smaller

  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-plugin/branch/improve_compile_times_scpeters?dest=ign-plugin1#diff

ABI checker is happy:

  • https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_plugin-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/12/API_5fABI_20report/

content.raw: Thanks for working on this! I'll take a look at it after our sub-t release process has quieted down.
content.html: Thanks for working on this! I'll take a look at it after our sub-t release process has quieted down.
